title: Donald Trump loses court battle to keep personal tax returns secret
text:

US President Donald Trump has lost his long-running court battle to keep his tax returns secret.

A federal judge has roundly rejected the leader's request to block a subpoena- meaning he must turn over eight years of his tax records.

The judge rejected the President's argument he is immune from being sued.

US District Judge Victor Marrero released today criticised Mr Trump and his lawyers for advancing an argument that the president, his family and businesses "associated with him in potentially unlawful private activities, are in fact above the law."

Mr Trump has not yet commented on today's finding.

(Image: REUTERS)

Today's development means the president cannot block Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance's request for eight years of his tax returns.

The prosecutor is probing allegations hush money was paid to two women, porn star Stormey Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal, ahead of the 2016 US Election.

Mr Vance issued the subpoena four weeks after issuing another subpoena to the Trump Organization for records of the payments to the two women who said they had sexual relationships with Mr Trump before the election, which he denies.

Judge Marrero in Manhattan today decided to abstain from resolving the dispute and dismissed Mr Trump's lawsuit, citing legal precedents.

Mr Vance had filed a subpoena for the tax returns and other records from Mr Trump's longtime accounting firm Mazars USA, in connection with a criminal probe into the president and his family business.

Mr Trump's claim that in his view a sitting President should be completely immune from criminal processes so he can carry out the role is described as "extraordinary" in today's decision.

The judge completely rejected the argument that Mr Trump should be immune to a criminal probe while in office.



He also rejected the Trump legal team's argument that the United States Constitution required Mr Vance to wait until after the president left the White House to look into his records.

The president has tried to keep many aspects of his finances under wraps, despite having promised during his 2016 White House run that he would disclose his tax returns.

Judge Marrero wrote that a president could not expect to be shielded from any judicial processes, whether they concerned his presidential or personal activities.

Handing the president total immunity could have potentially far-reaching consequences - blocking him and any associates from all judicial processes, his findings said.

He wrote that if Mr Trump's argument was accepted, it would lay the groundwork for any issues arising concerning the president, his businesses, or anyone associated with him, to be given a route to "escape being brought to justice."

The subpoena for Mr Trump's tax returns was served on Mazars by the district attorney on August 29.

It covers a request for documents and records, including the President's tax returns, covering the period from January 2011 to present.

In response, Mr Trump pursued a series of legal actions in an attempt to block the request.

Mazars has in the past said it would comply with its legal obligations, and as a matter of policy did not comment on its work for clients.

The president is separately trying to block Deutsche Bank from handing over financial records, which the bank has said include tax returns, sought by committees of the US House of Representatives.

That case has yet to be resolved.
description: A federal judge has blocked the US President's bid to keep his tax returns from being publicly scrutinised
